Section 19.4, “BT.2020 color primaries”

BT.2020

Section 18.2, “ITU transfer functions”

BT.2020

the section called “BT.2020 Y’CBCR conversion”

BT.709 Y’CBCR conversion

ITU Rec.709 defines $K_R = 0.2126$ and $K_B = 0.0722$ .

That is, for conversion between $(R', G', B')$ defined in BT.709 color primaries and using the ITU transfer function:

\begin{align*} Y' & = 0.2126 \times R' + 0.7152 \times G' + 0.0722 \times B' \\ C'_B & = {(B' - Y')\over{1.8556}} \\ C'_R & = {(R' - Y')\over{1.5748}} \\ \end{align*}

Alternatively:

$$\left(\begin{array}{c}Y' \\ C'_B \\ C'_R\end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{ccc}0.2126, & 0.7152, & 0.0722 \\ -{0.2126\over{1.8556}}, & -{0.7152\over{1.8556}}, & 0.5 \\ 0.5, & -{0.7152\over{1.5748}}, & -{0.0722\over{1.5748}}\end{array}\right) \left(\begin{array}{c}R'\\ G'\\ B'\end{array}\right)$$

For the inverse conversion:

$$\left(\begin{array}{c}R'\\ G'\\ B'\end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{ccc}1, & 0, & 1.5748\\ 1, & -{0.13397432\over{0.7152}}, & -{0.33480248\over{0.7152}}\\ 1, & 1.8556, & 0\end{array}\right) \left(\begin{array}{c}Y'\\ C'_B\\ C'_R\end{array}\right)$$

BT.601 Y’CBCR conversion

ITU Rec.601 defines $K_R = 0.299$ and $K_B = 0.114$ .

That is, for conversion between $(R', G', B')$ defined in BT.601 EBU color primaries or BT.601 SMPTE color primaries, and using the ITU transfer function:

\begin{align*} Y' & = 0.299 \times R' + 0.587 \times G' + 0.114 \times B' \\ C'_B & = {(B' - Y')\over{1.772}} \\ C'_R & = {(R' - Y')\over{1.402}} \\ \end{align*}

Alternatively:

$$\left(\begin{array}{c}Y' \\ C'_B \\ C'_R\end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{ccc}0.299, & 0.587, & 0.114 \\ -{0.299\over{1.772}}, & -{0.587\over{1.772}}, & 0.5 \\ 0.5, & -{0.587\over{1.402}}, & -{0.114\over{1.402}}\end{array}\right) \left(\begin{array}{c}R'\\ G'\\ B'\end{array}\right)$$

For the inverse conversion:

$$\left(\begin{array}{c}R'\\ G'\\ B'\end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{ccc}1, & 0, & 1.402\\ 1, & -{0.202008\over{0.587}}, & -{0.419198\over{0.587}}\\ 1, & 1.772, & 0\end{array}\right) \left(\begin{array}{c}Y'\\ C'_B\\ C'_R\end{array}\right)$$

BT.2020 Y’CBCR conversion

ITU Rec.2020 and ITU Rec.2100 define $K_R = 0.2627$ and $K_B = 0.0593$ .

That is, for conversion between $(R', G', B')$ defined in BT.2020 color primaries and using the ITU transfer function:

\begin{align*} Y' & = 0.2627 \times R' + 0.6780 \times G' + 0.0593 \times B' \\ C'_B & = {(B' - Y')\over{1.8814}} \\ C'_R & = {(R' - Y')\over{1.4746}} \\ \end{align*}

Alternatively:

$$\left(\begin{array}{c}Y' \\ C'_B \\ C'_R\end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{ccc}0.2627, & 0.6780, & 0.0593 \\ -{0.2627\over{1.8814}}, & -{0.6780\over{1.8814}}, & 0.5 \\ 0.5, & -{0.6780\over{1.4746}}, & -{0.0593\over{1.4746}}\end{array}\right) \left(\begin{array}{c}R'\\ G'\\ B'\end{array}\right)$$

For the inverse conversion:

$$\left(\begin{array}{c}R'\\ G'\\ B'\end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{ccc}1, & 0, & 1.4746\\ 1, & -{0.11156702\over{0.6780}}, & -{0.38737742\over{0.6780}}\\ 1, & 1.8814, & 0\end{array}\right) \left(\begin{array}{c}Y'\\ C'_B\\ C'_R\end{array}\right)$$

ST-240/SMPTE 240M Y’CBCR conversion

ST240, formerly SMPTE 240M, defines $K_R = 0.212$ and $K_B = 0.087$ .

That is, for conversion using the ST240 transfer function:

\begin{align*} Y' & = 0.212 \times R' + 0.701 \times G' + 0.087 \times B' \\ C'_B & = {(B' - Y')\over{1.826}} \\ C'_R & = {(R' - Y')\over{1.576}} \\ \end{align*}

Alternatively:

$$\left(\begin{array}{c}Y' \\ C'_B \\ C'_R\end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{ccc}0.212, & 0.701, & 0.087 \\ -{0.212\over{1.826}}, & -{0.701\over{1.826}}, & 0.5 \\ 0.5, & -{0.701\over{1.576}}, & -{0.087\over{1.576}}\end{array}\right) \left(\begin{array}{c}R'\\ G'\\ B'\end{array}\right)$$

For the inverse conversion:

$$\left(\begin{array}{c}R'\\ G'\\ B'\end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{ccc}1, & 0, & 1.576\\ 1, & -{0.58862\over{0.701}}, & -{0.334112\over{0.701}}\\ 1, & 1.826, & 0\end{array}\right) \left(\begin{array}{c}Y'\\ C'_B\\ C'_R\end{array}\right)$$

20.2. Y'CC'BCC'CR constant luminance color model

ITU-T Rec. BT.2020 introduced a “constant luminance” color representation as an alternative representation to $Y'C_BC_R$ :

\begin{align*} Y'_C & = (0.2627R + 0.6780G + 0.0593B)' \\ C'_{BC} & = \begin{cases} {{B'-Y'_C}\over{1.9404}}, & -0.9702 \leq B'-Y'_C \leq 0 \\ {{B'-Y'_C}\over{1.5816}}, & 0 < B'-Y'_C \leq 0.7908\end{cases} \\ C'_{RC} & = \begin{cases} {{R'-Y'_C}\over{1.7184}}, & -0.8592 \leq R'-Y'_C \leq 0 \\ {{R'-Y'_C}\over{0.9936}}, & 0 < R'-Y'_C \leq 0.4968\end{cases} \end{align*}

This terminology follow’s BT.2020’s convention of describing the continuous values as $Y'_C$ , $C'_{BC}$ and $C'_{RC}$ , BT.2020 uses $DY'_C$ , $DC'_{BC}$ and $DC'_{RC}$ to represent the quantized integer representations of the same values.

$Y'_C$ is derived from applying a non-linear transfer function to a combination of linear $RGB$ components and applying a non-linear transfer function to the result, but the $C'_{BC}$ and $C'_{RC}$ color differences still encode differences between non-linear values.

The inverse transformation can be derived from the above:

\begin{align*} B' & = \begin{cases} Y'_C + 1.9404C'_{BC}, & C'_{BC} \leq 0 \\ Y'_C + 1.5816C'_{BC}, & C'_{BC} > 0\end{cases}\\ R' & = \begin{cases} Y'_C + 1.7184C'_{RC}, & C'_{RC} \leq 0 \\ Y'_C + 0.9936C'_{RC}, & C'_{RC} > 0\end{cases}\\ G & = Y_C - 0.2627R - 0.0593B \end{align*}

Performing these calculations requires conversion between a linear representation and a non-linear transfer function during the transformation. This is distinct from the non-constant-luminance case, which is a simple matrix transform.

20.3. ICTCP constant intensity color model

ITU-T Rec. BT.2100 introduced a “constant intensity” color representation as an alternative representation to $Y'C_BC_R$ :

\begin{align*} L & = {(1688R + 2146G + 262B)\over{4096}}\\ M & = {(683R + 2951G + 462B)\over{4096}}\\ S & = {(99R + 309G + 3688B)\over{4096}}\\ L' & = \begin{cases} \textrm{EOTF}^{-1}(L_D), & \textrm{PQ transfer function}\\ \textrm{OETF}(L_S), & \textrm{HLG transfer function}\end{cases}\\ M' & = \begin{cases} \textrm{EOTF}^{-1}(M_D), & \textrm{PQ transfer function}\\ \textrm{OETF}(M_S), & \textrm{HLG transfer function}\end{cases}\\ S' & = \begin{cases} \textrm{EOTF}^{-1}(S_D), & \textrm{PQ transfer function}\\ \textrm{OETF}(S_S), & \textrm{HLG transfer function}\end{cases}\\ I & = 0.5L' + 0.5M'\\ C_T & = {(6610L' - 13613M' + 7003S')\over{4096}}\\ C_P & = {(17933L' - 17390M' - 543S')\over{4096}} \end{align*}

Note that the suffix D indicates that PQ encoding is display-referred and the suffix S indicates that HLG encoding is scene-referred - that is, they refer to display and scene light respectively.

To invert this, it can be observed that:

$$\left(\begin{array}{c}L' \\ M' \\ S' \end{array}\right) = 4096\times \left(\begin{array}{rrr}2048, & 2048, & 0 \\ 6610, & -13613, & 7003 \\ 17933, & -17390, & -543\end{array}\right)^{-1} \left(\begin{array}{c}I\\ C_T\\ C_P\end{array}\right)$$ $$\left(\begin{array}{c}L' \\ M' \\ S' \end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{rrr}1, & 1112064/129174029, & 14342144/129174029 \\ 1, & -1112064/129174029, & -14342144/129174029 \\ 1, & 72341504/129174029, & -41416704/129174029\end{array}\right) \left(\begin{array}{c}I\\ C_T\\ C_P\end{array}\right)$$ $$\left(\begin{array}{c}L' \\ M' \\ S' \end{array}\right) \approx \left(\begin{array}{rrr}1, & 0.0086090370, & 0.1110296250 \\ 1, & -0.0086090370, & -0.1110296250 \\ 1, & 0.5600313357, & -0.3206271750\end{array}\right) \left(\begin{array}{c}I\\ C_T\\ C_P\end{array}\right)$$ $$\{L_D,M_D,S_D\} = \textrm{EOTF}_{\textrm{PQ}}(\{L',M',S'\})$$ $$\{L_S,M_S,S_S\} = \textrm{OETF}_{\textrm{HLG}}^{-1}(\{L',M',S'\})$$ $$\left(\begin{array}{c}R \\ G \\ B\end{array}\right) = 4096\times \left(\begin{array}{rrr}1688, & 2146, & 262 \\ 683, & 2951, & 462 \\ 99, & 309, & 3688\end{array}\right)^{-1} \left(\begin{array}{c}L\\ M\\ S\end{array}\right)$$ $$\left(\begin{array}{c}R \\ G \\ B \end{array}\right) = {4096\over 12801351680}\times \left(\begin{array}{rrr}10740530, & -7833490, & 218290 \\ -2473166, & 6199406, & -600910 \\ -81102, & -309138, & 3515570\end{array}\right) \left(\begin{array}{c}L\\ M\\ S\end{array}\right)$$ $$\left(\begin{array}{c}R \\ G \\ B \end{array}\right) \approx \left(\begin{array}{rrr}3.4366066943, & -2.5064521187, & 0.0698454243 \\ -0.7913295556, & 1.9836004518, & -0.1922708962 \\ -0.0259498997, & -0.0989137147, & 1.1248636144\end{array}\right) \left(\begin{array}{c}L\\ M\\ S\end{array}\right)$$

21. Quantization schemes

The formulae in the previous sections are described in terms of operations on continuous values. These values are typically represented by quantized integers. There are standard encodings for representing some color models within a given bit depth range.

21.1. “Narrow range” encoding

ITU broadcast standards typically reserve values at the ends of the representable integer range for rounding errors and for signal control data. The nominal range of representable values between these limits is represented by the following encodings, for bit depth $n = \{8,10,12\}$ :

\begin{align*} DG' & = \lfloor 0.5 + (219\times G' + 16)\times 2^{n-8}\rfloor &DB' & = \lfloor 0.5 + (219\times B' + 16)\times 2^{n-8}\rfloor \\ &&DR' & = \lfloor 0.5 + (219\times R' + 16)\times 2^{n-8}\rfloor \\ DY' & = \lfloor 0.5 + (219\times Y' + 16)\times 2^{n-8}\rfloor &DC'_B & = \lfloor 0.5 + (224\times C'_B + 128)\times 2^{n-8}\rfloor \\ &&DC'_R & = \lfloor 0.5 + (224\times C'_R + 128)\times 2^{n-8}\rfloor \\ DY'_C & = \lfloor 0.5 + (219\times Y'_C + 16)\times 2^{n-8}\rfloor &DC'_{CB} & = \lfloor 0.5 + (224\times C'_{CB} + 128)\times 2^{n-8}\rfloor \\ &&DC'_{CR} & = \lfloor 0.5 + (224\times C'_{CR} + 128)\times 2^{n-8}\rfloor \\ DI & = \lfloor 0.5 + (219\times I + 16)\times 2^{n-8}\rfloor &DC'_T & = \lfloor 0.5 + (224\times C'_T + 128)\times 2^{n-8}\rfloor \\ &&DC'_P & = \lfloor 0.5 + (224\times C'_P + 128)\times 2^{n-8}\rfloor \end{align*}

The dequantization formulae are therefore:

\begin{align*} G' & = {{{DG'\over{2^{n-8}}} - 16}\over{219}} & Y' & = {{{DY'\over{2^{n-8}}} - 16}\over{219}} & Y'_C & = {{{DY_C'\over{2^{n-8}}} - 16}\over{219}} & I & = {{{DI'\over{2^{n-8}}} - 16}\over{219}} \\ B' & = {{{DB'\over{2^{n-8}}} - 16}\over{219}} & C'_B & = {{{DC'_B\over{2^{n-8}}} - 128}\over{224}} & C'_{CB} & = {{{DC'_{CB}\over{2^{n-8}}} - 128}\over{224}} & C'_T & = {{{DC'_T\over{2^{n-8}}} - 128}\over{224}} \\ R' & = {{{DR'\over{2^{n-8}}} - 16}\over{219}} & C'_R & = {{{DC'_R\over{2^{n-8}}} - 128}\over{224}} & C'_{CR} & = {{{DC'_{CR}\over{2^{n-8}}} - 128}\over{224}} & C'_P & = {{{DC'_P\over{2^{n-8}}} - 128}\over{224}} \end{align*}

For consistency with $Y'_CC'_{BC}C'_{RC}$ , these formulae use the BT.2020 and BT.2100 terminology of prefixing a $D$ to represent the digital quantized encoding of a numerical value.

That is, in “narrow range” encoding:

Value Continuous encoding value Quantized encoding

Black

{ $R'$ , $G'$ , $B'$ , $Y'$ , $Y'_C$ , $I$ } = $0.0$

{ $DR'$ , $DG'$ , $DB'$ , $DY'$ , $DY'_C$ , $DI$ } = $16 \times 2^{n-8}$

Peak brightness

{ $R'$ , $G'$ , $B'$ , $Y'$ , $Y'_C$ , $I$ } = $1.0$

{ $DR'$ , $DG'$ , $DB'$ , $DY'$ , $DY'_C$ , $DI$ } = $235 \times 2^{n-8}$

Minimum color difference value

{ $C'_B$ , $C'_R$ , $C'_{BC}$ , $C'_{RC}$ , $C_T$ , $C_P$ } = $-0.5$

{ $DC'_B$ , $DC'_R$ , $DC'_{BC}$ , $DC'_{CR}$ , $DC_T$ , $DC_P$ } = $16 \times 2^{n-8}$

Maximum color difference value

{ $C'_B$ , $C'_R$ , $C'_{BC}$ , $C'_{RC}$ , $C_T$ , $C_P$ } = $0.5$

{ $DC'_B$ , $DC'_R$ , $DC'_{BC}$ , $DC'_{CR}$ , $DC_T$ , $DC_P$ } = $240 \times 2^{n-8}$

Achromatic colors

$R'$ = $G'$ = $B'$

{ $C'_B$ , $C'_R$ , $C'_{BC}$ , $C'_{RC}$ , $C_T$ , $C_P$ } = $0.0$

{ $DC'_B$ , $DC'_R$ , $DC'_{BC}$ , $DC'_{CR}$ , $DC_T$ , $DC_P$ } = $128 \times 2^{n-8}$

If, instead of the quantized values, the input is interpreted as fixed-point values in the range 0.0..1.0, as might be the case if the values were treated as unsigned normalized quantities in a computer graphics API, the following conversions can be applied instead:

\begin{align*} G' & = {{{G'_{norm}\times{2^{n-1}}} - 16\times{2^{n-8}}}\over{219\times 2^{n-8}}} & B' & = {{{B'_{norm}\times{2^{n-1}}} - 16\times{2^{n-8}}}\over{219\times 2^{n-8}}} \\ &&R' & = {{{R'_{norm}\times{2^{n-1}}} - 16\times{2^{n-8}}}\over{219\times 2^{n-8}}} \\ Y' & = {{{Y'_{norm}\times{2^{n-1}}} - 16\times{2^{n-8}}}\over{219\times 2^{n-8}}} & C'_B & = {{{DC'_{Bnorm}\times{2^{n-1}}} - 128\times 2^{n-8}}\over{224\times 2^{n-8}}} \\ &&C'_R & = {{{DC'_{Rnorm}\times{2^{n-1}}} - 128\times 2^{n-8}}\over{224\times 2^{n-8}}} \\ Y'_C & = {{{Y'_{Cnorm}\times{2^{n-1}}} - 16\times{2^{n-8}}}\over{219\times 2^{n-8}}} & C'_{CB} & = {{{DC'_{CBnorm}\times{2^{n-1}}} - 128\times 2^{n-8}}\over{224\times 2^{n-8}}} \\ &&C'_{CR} & = {{{DC'_{CRnorm}\times{2^{n-1}}} - 128\times 2^{n-8}}\over{224\times 2^{n-8}}} \\ I & = {{{I'_{norm}\times{2^{n-1}}} - 16\times{2^{n-8}}}\over{219\times 2^{n-8}}} & C'_T & = {{{DC'_{Tnorm}\times{2^{n-1}}} - 128\times 2^{n-8}}\over{224\times 2^{n-8}}} \\ &&C'_P & = {{{DC'_{Pnorm}\times{2^{n-1}}} - 128\times 2^{n-8}}\over{224\times 2^{n-8}}} \\ G'_{norm} & = {{{G'\times{219\times 2^{n-8}}} + 16\times{2^{n-8}}}\over{2^{n-1}}} & B'_{norm} & = {{{B'\times{219\times 2^{n-8}}} + 16\times{2^{n-8}}}\over{2^{n-1}}} \\ &&R'_{norm} & = {{{R'\times{219\times 2^{n-8}}} + 16\times{2^{n-8}}}\over{2^{n-1}}} \\ Y'_{norm} & = {{{Y'\times{219\times 2^{n-8}}} + 16\times{2^{n-8}}}\over{2^{n-1}}} & C'_{Bnorm} & = {{{DC'_B\times{224\times ^{n-8}}} + 128\times 2^{n-8}}\over{2^{n-1}}} \\ &&C'_{Rnorm} & = {{{DC'_R\times{224\times ^{n-8}}} + 128\times 2^{n-8}}\over{2^{n-1}}} \\ Y'_{Cnorm} & = {{{Y'_C\times{219\times 2^{n-8}}} + 16\times{2^{n-8}}}\over{2^{n-1}}} & C'_{CBnorm} & = {{{DC'_{CB}\times{224\times ^{n-8}}} + 128\times 2^{n-8}}\over{2^{n-1}}} \\ &&C'_{CRnorm} & = {{{DC'_{CR}\times{224\times ^{n-8}}} + 128\times 2^{n-8}}\over{2^{n-1}}} \\ I_{norm} & = {{{I\times{219\times 2^{n-8}}} + 16\times{2^{n-8}}}\over{2^{n-1}}} & C'_{Tnorm} & = {{{DC'_{T}\times{224\times ^{n-8}}} + 128\times 2^{n-8}}\over{2^{n-1}}} \\ &&C'_{Pnorm} & = {{{DC'_{P}\times{224\times ^{n-8}}} + 128\times 2^{n-8}}\over{2^{n-1}}} \end{align*}

21.2. “Full range” encoding

ITU-T Rec. BT.2100-1 and the current Rec. T.871 JFIF specification define the following quantization scheme that does not incorporate any reserved head-room or foot-room, which is optional and described as “full range” in BT.2100, and integral to Rec. T.871.

Both these specifications modify a definition used in previous versions of their specifications, which is described below.

For bit depth $n = \{8$ (JFIF) $,10,12$ (Rec.2100) $\}$ :

\begin{align*} DG' & = \textrm{Round}\left(G'\times (2^n-1)\right) & DB' & = \textrm{Round}\left(B'\times (2^n-1)\right) \\ &&DR' & = \textrm{Round}\left(R'\times (2^n-1)\right) \\ DY' & = \textrm{Round}\left(Y'\times (2^n-1)\right) & DC'_B & = \textrm{Round}\left(C'_B\times (2^n-1) + 2^{n-1}\right) \\ &&DC'_R & = \textrm{Round}\left(C'_R\times (2^n-1) + 2^{n-1}\right) \\ DY'_C & = \textrm{Round}\left(Y'_C\times (2^n-1)\right) & DC'_{CB} & = \textrm{Round}\left(C'_{CB}\times (2^n-1) + 2^{n-1}\right) \\ &&DC'_{CR} & = \textrm{Round}\left(C'_{CR}\times (2^n-1) + 2^{n-1}\right) \\ DI & = \textrm{Round}\left(I\times (2^n-1)\right) & DC'_T & = \textrm{Round}\left(C'_T\times (2^n-1) + 2^{n-1}\right) \\ &&DC'_P & = \textrm{Round}\left(C'_P\times (2^n-1) + 2^{n-1}\right) \end{align*}

BT.2100-1 defines Round() as:

\begin{align*} \textrm{Round}(x) &= \textrm{Sign}(x)\times\lfloor|x| + 0.5\rfloor \\ \textrm{Sign}(x) &= \begin{cases} 1, & x > 0 \\ 0, & x = 0 \\ -1, & x < 0 \end{cases} \end{align*}

Note that a chroma channel value of exactly 0.5 corresponds to a quantized encoding of $2^n$ , and must therefore be clamped to the nominal peak value of $2^n-1$ . Narrow-range encoding does not have this problem. A chroma channel value of -0.5 corresponds to a quantized encoding of 1, which is the nominal minimum peak value.

In Rec. T.871 (which defines only n = 8), the corresponding formula is:

\begin{align*} \textrm{Round}(x) &= \textrm{Clamp}(\lfloor|x| + 0.5\rfloor) \\ \textrm{clamp}(x) &= \begin{cases} 255, & x > 255 \\ 0, & x < 0 \\ x, & \textrm{otherwise} \end{cases} \end{align*}

Allowing for the clamping at a chroma value of 0.5, these formulae are equivalent across the expected -0.5..0.5 range for chroma and 0.0..1.0 range for luma values.

The dequantization formulae are therefore:

\begin{align*} G' & = {DG'\over{2^n - 1}} & Y' & = {DY'\over{2^n - 1}} & Y'_C & = {DY_C'\over{2^n - 1}} & I & = {DI'\over{2^n - 1}} \\ B' & = {DB'\over{2^n - 1}} & C'_B & = {DC'_B - 2^{n-1}\over{2^n - 1}} & C'_{CB} & = {DC'_{CB} - 2^{n-1}\over{2^n - 1}} & C'_T & = {DC'_T - 2^{n-1}\over{2^n - 1}} \\ R' & = {DR'\over{2^n - 1}} & C'_R & = {DC'_R - 2^{n-1}\over{2^n - 1}} & C'_{CR} & = {DC'_{CR} - 2^{n-1}\over{2^n - 1}} & C'_P & = {DC'_P - 2^{n-1}\over{2^n - 1}} \end{align*}

That is, in “full range” encoding:

Value Continuous encoding value Quantized encoding

Black

{ $R'$ , $G'$ , $B'$ , $Y'$ , $Y'_C$ , $I$ } = $0.0$

{ $DR'$ , $DG'$ , $DB'$ , $DY'$ , $DY'_C$ , $DI$ } = $0$

Peak brightness

{ $R'$ , $G'$ , $B'$ , $Y'$ , $Y'_C$ , $I$ } = $1.0$

{ $DR'$ , $DG'$ , $DB'$ , $DY'$ , $DY'_C$ , $DI$ } = $2^n - 1$

Minimum color difference value

{ $C'_B$ , $C'_R$ , $C'_{BC}$ , $C'_{RC}$ , $C_T$ , $C_P$ } = $-0.5$

{ $DC'_B$ , $DC'_R$ , $DC'_{BC}$ , $DC'_{CR}$ , $DC_T$ , $DC_P$ } = $1$

Maximum color difference value

{ $C'_B$ , $C'_R$ , $C'_{BC}$ , $C'_{RC}$ , $C_T$ , $C_P$ } = $0.5$

{ $DC'_B$ , $DC'_R$ , $DC'_{BC}$ , $DC'_{CR}$ , $DC_T$ , $DC_P$ } = $2^n - 1$

(clamped)

Achromatic colors

$R'$ = $G'$ = $B'$

{ $C'_B$ , $C'_R$ , $C'_{BC}$ , $C'_{RC}$ , $C_T$ , $C_P$ } = $0.0$

{ $DC'_B$ , $DC'_R$ , $DC'_{BC}$ , $DC'_{CR}$ , $DC_T$ , $DC_P$ } = $2^{n-1}$

If, instead of the quantized values, the input is interpreted as fixed-point values in the range 0.0..1.0, as might be the case if the values were treated as unsigned normalized quantities in a computer graphics API, the following conversions can be applied instead:

\begin{align*} G' & = G'_{norm} & B' & = B'_{norm} \\ &&R' & = R'_{norm} \\ Y' & = Y'_{norm} & C'_B & = DC'_{Bnorm} - {2^{n-1}\over{2^n - 1}} \\ &&C'_R & = DC'_{Rnorm} - {2^{n-1}\over{2^n - 1}} \\ Y'_C & = Y'_{Cnorm} & C'_{CB} & = DC'_{CBnorm} - {2^{n-1}\over{2^n - 1}} \\ &&C'_{CR} & = DC'_{CRnorm} - {2^{n-1}\over{2^n - 1}} \\ I & = I'_{norm} & C'_T & = DC'_{Tnorm} - {2^{n-1}\over{2^n - 1}} \\ &&C'_P & = DC'_{Pnorm} - {2^{n-1}\over{2^n - 1}} \\ G'_{norm} & = G' & B'_{norm} & = B' \\ &&R'_{norm} & = R' \\ Y'_{norm} & = Y' & C'_{Bnorm} & = DC'_B + {2^{n-1}\over{2^n - 1}} \\ &&C'_{Rnorm} & = DC'_R + {2^{n-1}\over{2^n - 1}} \\ Y'_{Cnorm} & = Y'_C & C'_{CBnorm} & = DC'_{CB} + {2^{n-1}\over{2^n - 1}} \\ &&C'_{CRnorm} & = DC'_{CR} + {2^{n-1}\over{2^n - 1}} \\ I_{norm} & = I & C'_{Tnorm} & = DC'_{T} + {2^{n-1}\over{2^n - 1}} \\ &&C'_{Pnorm} & = DC'_{P} + {2^{n-1}\over{2^n - 1}} \end{align*}

21.3. Legacy “full range” encoding.

ITU-T Rec. BT.2100-0 formalized an optional encoding scheme that does not incorporate any reserved head-room or foot-room. The legacy JFIF specification similarly used the full range of 8-bit channels to represent $Y'C_BC_R$ color. For bit depth $n = \{8$ (JFIF) $,10,12$ (Rec.2100) $\}$ :

\begin{align*} DG' & = \lfloor 0.5 + G'\times 2^n\rfloor & DB' & = \lfloor 0.5 + B'\times 2^n\rfloor \\ &&DR' & = \lfloor 0.5 + R'\times 2^n\rfloor \\ DY' & = \lfloor 0.5 + Y'\times 2^n\rfloor & DC'_B & = \lfloor 0.5 + (C'_B + 0.5)\times 2^n\rfloor \\ &&DC'_R & = \lfloor 0.5 + (C'_R + 0.5)\times 2^n\rfloor \\ DY'_C & = \lfloor 0.5 + Y'_C\times 2^n\rfloor & DC'_{CB} & = \lfloor 0.5 + (C'_{CB} + 0.5)\times 2^n\rfloor \\ &&DC'_{CR} & = \lfloor 0.5 + (C'_{CR} + 0.5)\times 2^n\rfloor \\ DI & = \lfloor 0.5 + I\times 2^n\rfloor & DC'_T & = \lfloor 0.5 + (C'_T + 0.5)\times 2^n\rfloor \\ &&DC'_P & = \lfloor 0.5 + (C'_P + 0.5)\times 2^n\rfloor \end{align*}

The dequantization formulae are therefore:

\begin{align*} G' & = DG'\times 2^{-n} & Y' & = DY'\times 2^{-n} & Y'_C & = DY_C'\times 2^{-n} & I & = DI'\times 2^{-n} \\ B' & = DB'\times 2^{-n} & C'_B & = DC'_B\times 2^{-n}-0.5 & C'_{CB} & = DC'_{CB}\times 2^{-n}-0.5 & C'_T & = DC'_T\times 2^{-n}-0.5 \\ R' & = DR'\times 2^{-n} & C'_R & = DC'_R\times 2^{-n}-0.5 & C'_{CR} & = DC'_{CR}\times 2^{-n}-0.5 & C'_P & = DC'_P\times 2^{-n}-0.5 \end{align*}

These formulae map luma values of 1.0 and chroma values of 0.5 to $2^n$ , for bit depth $n$ . This has the effect that the maximum value (e.g. pure white) cannot be represented directly. Out-of-bounds values must be clamped to the largest representable value.

ITU-R BT.2100-0 dictates that in 12-bit coding, the largest values encoded should be 4092 (“for consistency” with 10-bit encoding, with a maximum value of 1023). This slightly reduces the maximum intensity which can be expressed, and slightly reduces the saturation range. The achromatic color point is still 2048 in the 12-bit case, so no offset is applied in the transformation to compensate for this range reduction.

If, instead of the quantized values, the input is interpreted as fixed-point values in the range 0.0..1.0, as might be the case if the values were treated as unsigned normalized quantities in a computer graphics API, the following conversions can be applied instead:

\begin{align*} G' & = {{G'_{norm}\times (2^n-1)}\over{2^n}} & B' & = {{B'_{norm}\times (2^n-1)}\over{2^n}} & R' & = {{R'_{norm}\times (2^n-1)}\over{2^n}} \\ Y' & = {{Y'_{norm}\times (2^n-1)}\over{2^n}} & C'_B & = {{C'_{Bnorm}\times (2^n-1)}\over{2^n}} - 0.5 & C'_R & = {{C'_{Rnorm}\times (2^n-1)}\over{2^n}} - 0.5 \\ Y'_C & = {{Y_{Cnorm}'\times (2^n-1)}\over{2^n}} & C'_{CB} & = {{C'_{CBnorm}\times (2^n-1)}\over{2^n}} - 0.5 & C'_{CR} & = {{C'_{CRnorm}\times (2^n-1)}\over{2^n}} - 0.5 \\ I & = {{I'_{norm}\times (2^n-1)}\over{2^n}} & C'_T & = {{C'_{Tnorm}\times (2^n-1)}\over{2^n}} - 0.5 & C'_P & = {{C'_{Pnorm}\times (2^n-1)}\over{2^n}} - 0.5 \end{align*}
\begin{align*} G_{norm}' & = {{G'\times 2^n}\over{2^n-1}} & B_{norm}' & = {{B'\times 2^n}\over{2^n-1}} & R_{norm}' & = {{R'\times 2^n}\over{2^n-1}} \\ Y_{norm}' & = {{Y'\times 2^n}\over{2^n-1}} & C'_{Bnorm} & = {{(C'_{B} + 0.5)\times 2^n}\over{2^n-1}} & C'_{Rnorm} & = {{(C'_{R} + 0.5)\times 2^n}\over{2^n-1}} \\ Y'_{Cnorm} & = {{Y_{C}'\times 2^n}\over{2^n-1}} & C'_{CBnorm} & = {{(C'_{CB} + 0.5)\times 2^n}\over{2^n-1}} & C'_{CRnorm} & = {{(C'_{CR} + 0.5)\times 2^n}\over{2^n-1}} \\ I_{norm} & = {{I'\times 2^n}\over{2^n-1}} & C'_{Tnorm} & = {{(C'_{T} + 0.5)\times 2^n}\over{2^n-1}} & C'_{Pnorm} & = {{(C'_{P} + 0.5)\times 2^n}\over{2^n-1}} \end{align*}

That is, to match the behavior described in these specifications, the inputs to color model conversion should be expanded such that the maximum representable value is that defined by the quantization of these encodings (255/256, 1023/1024 or 4095/4096), and the inverse operation should be applied to the result of the model conversion.

For example, a legacy shader-based JPEG decoder may read values in a normalized 0..1 range, where the in-memory value 0 represents 0.0 and the in-memory value 1 represents 1.0. The decoder should scale the $Y'$ value by a factor of 255/256 to match the encoding in the JFIF3 document, and $C'_B$ and $C_R$ should be scaled by 255/256 and offset by 0.5. After the model conversion matrix has been applied, the $R'$ , $G'$ and $B'$ values should be scaled by 256/255, restoring the ability to represent pure white.

1 (bit_length)

0 (channel_type) (Y)

0x7FFF (sample_upper) - top 16 bits of sample_upper

10 (bit_length)

0 (channel_type) (red)

0 (sample_position_0)

0 (sample_position_1)

0 (sample_position_2)

0 (sample_position_3)

0xbf80000 (sample_lower) = -1.0

0x3f80000 (sample_upper) = 1.0
